The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include new credits for flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicles and qualified alternative fuel motor vehicles. The new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicle credit is determined under subsection (e) and the new qualified alternative fuel motor vehicle credit is determined under subsection (f). The credit amount for the new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicle is based on the vehicle placed in service during the taxable year. The credit amount for a new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicle placed in service during the taxable year is determined under paragraph (2) based on a table provided in the subsection. The credit amount for a new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicle is determined based on the city fuel economy percentage compared to a comparable vehicle, ranging from $1,500 to $3,500. The city fuel economy of a new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicle is determined on an E-85 ethanol gallon equivalent basis, while the comparable vehicle is determined on a gasoline gallon equivalent basis. The new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicle must be capable of operating on alternative fuel, gasoline, or any blend, and achieve a city fuel economy using E-85 ethanol of at least 125. The text discusses the certification requirements for a new flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicle to qualify for a city fuel economy using E-85 ethanol that is at least 125% of a comparable nonhybrid vehicle fueled by gasoline. Additionally, it mentions the extension of termination for the tax credit for such vehicles until December 31, 2014. The Code is amended to include new provisions for flexible fuel hybrid motor vehicles, extending the tax credit termination date to December 31, 2014. Amendments are made to sections regarding numeric limitations and conforming amendments. Amendments are made to sections regarding numeric limitations and conforming amendments, including redesignating subsections and inserting new descriptions for qualified hybrid motor vehicles. The amendments made to the Code include changes to subsections and descriptions for qualified hybrid motor vehicles. The effective date for these amendments is after December 31, 2006.
